com.ibm.team.repository.client.util

Class EventSource

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ibm.team.repository.client.util.EventSource
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEventSource

    public class EventSource
extends java.lang.Object
implements IEventSource
    Implementation of the IEventSource interface. the parent event source whose generic listeners receive this event source's events; may be null

    Note: The event source maintains separate lists of typed and generic listeners.

    Since:
    0.5
    See Also:
    IEventSource

    • Method Detail

      • addGenericListener

        public final void addGenericListener(java.lang.Object category,
                      IListener listener)
        Adds a generic listener to this event source. Has no effect if an identical listener is registered already. Implementers of these listeners should never block the calling thread to wait for user input. If it is necessary to prompt the user, this must be done asynchronously.

        The added listener will be notified of future events classified under the given category. The notification will be via a call to the listener's IListener.handleEvents(List) method.

        The client may register the same listener instance against multiple event categories. However, it is the client's responsibility to keep track of such things, and unregister the listener when it is no longer needed. Failing to do so leaks the listener object, which is hung on to by the event source. Even more seriously, the listener wastes time because it continues to receive event notifications in perpetuity.

        Specified by:
        addGenericListener in interface IEventSource
        Parameters:
        category - the event category, typically the event type; must not be null
        listener - the listener; must not be null

      • removeGenericListener

        public final void removeGenericListener(java.lang.Object category,
                         IListener listener)
        Removes a generic listener previously added to this event source for the given category. The listener is only removed from the given category; its registration vis a vis other categories is not affected. Has no effect if the listener is not registered against the given category.
        Specified by:
        removeGenericListener in interface IEventSource
        Parameters:
        category - the event category; must not be null
        listener - the listener; must not be null

      • purgeGenericListener

        public final void purgeGenericListener(IListener listener)
        Removes a generic listener previously added to this event source for any category. The listener is removed from all categories it is registered under. Has no effect if the listener is not registered.
        Specified by:
        purgeGenericListener in interface IEventSource
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener; must not be null

      • addTypedListener

        public final void addTypedListener(java.lang.Object category,
                    java.lang.Object listener)
        Adds a typed listener to this event source. Has no effect if an identical typed listener is registered already. Implementers of these listeners should never block the calling thread to wait for user input. If it is necessary to prompt the user, this must be done asynchronously.

        The added listener will be notified of future events classified under the given category. The notification will be via the event source's dispatchEvents(Object, List) method.

        The client may register the same listener instance against multiple event categories. However, it is the client's responsibility to keep track of such things, and deregister the listener when it is no longer needed. Failing to do so leaks the listener object, which is hung on to by the event source. Even more seriously, the listener wastes time because it continues to receive event notifications in perpetuity.

        Parameters:
        category - the event category; must not be null
        listener - the typed listener; must not be null

      • removeTypedListener

        public final void removeTypedListener(java.lang.Object category,
                       java.lang.Object listener)
        Removes a typed listener previously added to this event source for the given category. The listener is only removed from the given category; its registration vis a vis other categories is not affected. Has no effect if the listener is not registered against the given category.
        Parameters:
        category - the event category; must not be null
        listener - the listener; must not be null

      • purgeTypedListener

        public final void purgeTypedListener(java.lang.Object listener)
        Removes a typed listener previously added to this event source for any category. The listener is removed from all categories it is registered under. Has no effect if the listener is not registered.
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener; must not be null

      • queueEvent

        public final void queueEvent(java.lang.Object event)
        Queues an event for later dispatching to listeners.

        This method is ordinarily called within the dynamic scope of acquire-release. However, if it isn't, one will be provided, ensuring that all events emanating from this event source are suitably serialized.

        In order to notify listeners, an event must be classified. If event instanceof IEvent, the event will be classified via event.getCategories(). Otherwise, the event will be classified via getCategoriesForEvent(event).

        Parameters:
        event - the event to queue; must not be null

      • acquire

        public final void acquire()
        Acquires this event source's lock. The invoking thread will block if the lock has already been acquired by another thread and not yet released. The lock is re-entrant: if the invoking thread has already acquired the lock, it will re-acquire it without blocking. It's critical that code that acquires the lock also releases it. Failing to release an event source lock will likely cause deadlocks. The following code pattern is strongly recommended because it ensures that every call to acquire is matched by a call to release: 
                      try {
                 acquire();
                 ...
              } finally {
                 release();
              }
        See Also:
        release()

      • release

        public final void release()
        Releases this event source's lock. If the thread acquires the lock multiple times, it must call release an equal number of times in order to truly release it. The invoking thread must have acquired the lock and not yet released it. See acquire() for the recommended code pattern for acquiring and releasing locks.

        Any events queued with this event source while the lock was held become eligible to be dispatched to interested listeners. The dispatching of event notifications may happen asynchronously. The caller must not assume that event notifications have been processed by the time this method completes.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalMonitorStateException - - if the current thread is not the holder of the lock
        See Also:
        acquire()

      • getCategoriesForEvent

        protected java.util.List getCategoriesForEvent(java.lang.Object event)
        Returns the non-empty list of categories for the given event. Categories must be distinct non-null objects that can be compared with equals.

        A typed event listener is registered against a category, entitling it to receive notifications of events in that category. Event objects that implement IEvent are self-categorizing. Other event objects are categorized by calling this method.

        The default implementation of this method throws UnsupportedOperationException. Override this method if the event source has event objects that do not implement IEvent. The resulting list must include at least one entry.

        Returns:
        the non-empty list of non-null categories (element type: Object); the list is never null; the list is immutable
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is needed but has not provided
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this event source uses non-IEvent event objects and no suitable implementation of this method has been provided in the subclass
        See Also:
        IEvent.getCategories()

      • dispatchEvents

        protected void dispatchEvents(java.lang.Object typedListener,
                  java.util.List events)
        Dispatches the given events to the given typed listener. The typed listener is an object that was passed to addTypedListener(Object, Object). The events are objects that were passed to queueEvent(Object).

        The default implementation of this method throws UnsupportedOperationException. Override this method if typed listeners are added to this event source via addTypedListener(Object, Object).

        Parameters:
        typedListener - the typed listener to be notified; must not be null
        events - the list of event objects (element type: Object); must not be null
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this event source uses typed listeners and no suitable implementation of this method has been provided in the subclass
        See Also:
        IEvent.getCategories()

      • internalIsBusy

        public final boolean internalIsBusy()
        Internal method; do not use.

        This method is provided so that the unit tests can verify that events are being properly dispatched.

        Returns:
        true if the event source is currently dispatching events to event listeners; otherwise false
